thread.title: Overall and Market Demand Fell for 26-Week Treasury Bills - Yahoo Finance
thread.title_full: Overall and Market Demand Fell for 26-Week Treasury Bills - Yahoo Finance

author: Lynn Noah
title: Overall and Market Demand Fell for 26-Week Treasury Bills - Yahoo Finance
text:
Demand for Treasuries Rises amid Worries of Global Growth Slowdown 
( Continued from Prior Part )
26-week T-bill auction On October 13, 2015, the US Department of the Treasury held the weekly auction for 26-week Treasury bills (or T-bills). The auction offered $20 billion in T-bills, which was $1 billion lower than the previous weekâ€™s auction.
The bid-to-cover ratio fell 2.9% from the previous week to 3.8x. In 2015 so far, the bid-to-cover ratio has averaged 4.1x. The ratio depicts the overall demand for the auction.

Yield analysis Treasury bills do not pay a coupon. They are offered at a discount to face value, and they are redeemable at par on maturity. The high discount rate for the October 13 auction came in at 0.080%, up from 0.065% in the previous week.
Market demand falls Fundamental market demand fell last week. Accepted indirect bids fell to 26.3% week-over-week from 31.3% in the previous week. Indirect bids are bids from the foreign central bank and depict international demand for auction.
Meanwhile, the percentage of direct bids rose to 7.0% week-over-week from 6.4% a week ago. Direct bids include bids from domestic money managers such as Wells Fargo (WFC) and State Street Corp (STT).
Due to lower market demand, the share of primary dealer bids rose to 66.7% of the auction from 62.3% in the previous week. Primary dealers are a group of 22 authorized broker-dealers that are obligated to bid at US Treasury auctions and take up excess supply. They include firms like Goldman Sachs (GS) and Citigroup Global Markets (C). A rise in the percentage of primary dealer bids indicates weak fundamental market demand.
Investment impact Mutual funds such as the Vanguard GNMA Fund Investor Shares Fund (VFIIX) and the Prudential Government Income Fund (PGVAX) invest in T-bills. VFIIX provided a weekly return of 0.21% while the week-over-week return of PGVAX came in at 0.32%.
